title: Linux (Gnome DE) `code-workspace` MimeType support
body:
In the Gnome desktop environment there isn't a MimeType associated with workspace files `*.code-workspace` and thus, they are opened with the default application registered for file type `text/plain`, (If I try to change the default app, all plaintext files default app are changed along with it).

It would be very beneficial to have a separate MimeType associated with `code-workspace` for usability i.e. the ability to have the file icon use the VSCode icon, and for double-click to open the workspace in VSCode.

title: Unable to disable middle click paste on OSX
body:
Middle click causes clipboard contents to paste.  This used to be a feature that could be disabled via "editor.selectionClipboard": "false", but that doesn't appear to be recognized nor work anymore.  This is problematic because my middle click button is mapped to other keystrokes so the results are unexpected.

- VSCode Version: 1.38.1
- OS Version: MacOS Mojave 10.14.6
- Mouse: Logitech MX Master 2s and Marathon M705

Steps to Reproduce:
Prereq: I have middle click mapped to CMD+W to close a tab, but reproduced with multiple other mappings
1. Copy text from anywhere
2. Open a new tab
3. Press middle click
4. Note that the copied text is now pasted

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Make number of items in "Open Recent" -> folders/files configurable
body:
I work with something like 20-30 different projects in a regular basis. Right now, only 10 items are shown in the File -> Open Recent -> Folders section, which requires a lot of manual opening.

It would be great of the number of items in both sections are configurable. Then I could set the number of folders to 20 and the number of files to 0. This would give me a noticable productivity boost.

title: JSDoc @author tag email address is obfuscated
body: - VSCode Version: 1.38.1 - OS Version: macOS Mojave 10.14.6 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a TS file with some code (empty class/function, anything that can be annotated with JSDoc) 2. Add `@author` JSDoc with email address and then hover/click on the email in the popup Note the parsed JSDoc message from TypeScript server in output log, it sends the email address correctly (unobfuscated). Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: Yes

title: Add more scopes to Dark+ and Light+ themes
body:
Original context: https://github.com/jeff-hykin/cpp-textmate-grammar/issues/388

We should look into adding some of the scopes from https://github.com/microsoft/vscode-cpptools/blob/master/Themes/themes/cpptools_dark_vs.json into the Dark+ and Light+ themes to better highlight C++. If other grammars use those scopes it could improve highlighting for them too.

title: Grid: toggling fullscreen results in 2 layout calls

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body: It looks like there is a `layout()` call from within the `layout()` call which sounds like trouble. Ideally doing an operation such as toggling fullscreen results in 1 `layout()` call.

title: STDIN file extension support
body:
Allow doing something like: ```more some.yml | code --file-extension yml -```. 

This would allow having the right editor kind right away instead of having a .txt file and having to rename it (or which ever other gesture to get the right editor).

Willing to contribute if idea is accepted.

title: Missing error details from test
body:
- Have extension test code that throws an error at the top level (outside of a test)
- Run the test, the error message shows up in the console, but the full stack is nowhere to be seen
- Be confused and spend awhile hunting for the source

This is sort of the opposite of https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/issues/76096 but we can probably satisfy both.

title: Question: Why did you favor "Data Breakpoint" over "Watchpoint"?
body:
Congrats on shipping "Data Breakpoints"! 

We've been working on a similar [feature][f] in Firefox. Server support landed a couple weeks ago and we just added [support][pr] in our vs code adapter. Our MVP UI will hopefully land in nightly this week and ride the trains. 

I'd love to learn more about how you arrived at the name "Data Breakpoint" [doc][doc]. Historically, the feature is referred to as watchpoints [gdb] and is analogous to other features like Logpoints. Are there other examples where the term "data breakpoint" is used?



[f]: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=dbg-watchpoints
[pr]: https://github.com/firefox-devtools/vscode-firefox-debug/pull/118
[doc]: https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/editor/debugging#_data-breakpoints
[gdb]: http://www.unknownroad.com/rtfm/gdbtut/gdbwatch.html#targetText=Watchpoints%20are%20similar%20to%20breakpoints,triggered%20and%20program%20execution%20stops.

title: Reveal closer to top (center body, not signature)
body:
This improves the jump to definition and outline UX esp. for long functions/classes.

Fixes #80726 (see issue description for reasoning behind this PR).

title: Reveal closer to top instead of center: outline, go to definition, etc.
body:
This is a UX improvement suggestion for "Go to definition" and when selecting an item from the outline. Note that JetBrains IDEs behave similar to this suggestion, so someone there thought about this issue, too.

If I asked you (i.e. a human) to scroll to a certain function or class, where would you position that function on the screen? You'd probably try to ensure that:

* the whole class/function is visible (including signature, body)
* comments preceding the function signature are also visible unless they're very long
* maybe for functions longer than a few lines the whole body would be centered on the screen (though, I've often seen developers not care too much as long as the whole body is visible)

A simplification of those rules is: Scroll the definition close to the top, but not exactly to the top, so the comments (and some extra context in case of variable definitions) are still visible.

Currently, "Go to definition" and other operations **center** the function **signature** within the window.

It would be more ergonomic to position the result closer to the top of the window because then you can see longer class/function definitions without scrolling and **most** of the code after the definition is usually more important than **most** of the code before the definition. We just have to ensure that sufficient context from before the definition is visible.

So, my suggestion is to have it revealed at around 20% of the screen height. I've tested that value and had some good experience with it. 15% might also be fine. IMHO, we shouldn't go beyond 25%.

title: json.schemas setting for matching schema based on a JSON property in the file
body:
Currently in VS Code we can load JSON schemas based on a setting that matches the file path...

```json
"json.schemas": [
    {
        "fileMatch": [
            "openapi.json"
        ],
        "url": "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/master/schemas/v3.0/schema.json"
    }
]
```

We can also add a new property to the top of our JSON to load a schema for that specific file...
```
{
    "$schema": "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/master/schemas/v3.0/schema.json",
    ...
```

What would be especially useful is if we could combine these functionalities so we could match an arbitrary property instead of `"$schema"` to load a schema file from the settings...

My use case is **OpenAPI** where the `"$schema"` property is not valid according to the OpenAPI JSON Schema. I'd like to resolve this as follows:

*.vscode/settings.json*
```json
"json.schemas": [
    {
        "fileMatch": [
            "openapi.json",
            {
                "path": "*.json",
                "property": "openapi",
                "value": "3.*"
            }
        ],
        "url": "https://raw.githubusercontent.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/master/schemas/v3.0/schema.json"
    }
]
```

Here we have backward compatibility with the path string version, whilst also introducing an object version where we can specify a property to match, and even it's value...

...for performance it may be necessary to mandate this is always the first property in the JSON object as I believe is the case with the current `"$schema" implementation.

title: VS Code crashing on restart after opening large file once with —max-memory=12288
body:
- VSCode Version: 1.38
- OS Version: Win 10 (1809) 17763.678

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a large file 10GB (original opened using `--max-memory=12288mb`). Observe that VS Code works fine handling the large file
2. Close VS code (note VS code options were previously set to hot close and restore on close)
3. Opening any VS Code window, either normally or through the context menu will cause the old large file to be loaded on open
4. At this point vs code will crash on opening within ~10 seconds. It will be functional within these 10 seconds but manual trying to close the window, file or editor will not have any effect. (Unfortunately I didn't take a screenshot of the error window but the dialog options were 'restart' which would reopen and perform perform steps 3. Onward again or just close the application)
5. Attempting to change hot reload setting or restore previous state options during the functioning 10 seconds before crash take no effect on restart

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7859942/64691488-a88e8a80-d48a-11e9-969d-8bb3285e3a9f.png)

Does this issue occur when all extensions are disabled?: No

The solution is to start VS Code through the command line with the `--max-memory=12288mb` argument and to manually close the document to prevent attempting to hot reload. 

I'll attach the seetting.json. Note that I've commented the settings that I added as part of step 5, these weren't present originally.

```
{
    "workbench.colorTheme": "Visual Studio Light",
    "editor.renderWhitespace": "all",
    // "window.restoreWindows": "none",
    // "files.hotExit": "off"
}
```

title: Workspace shell permissions are not remembered in multi-root workspaces

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
My workflow requires the use of cygwin in particular workspaces, so I have my *workspace settings* set up to default to cygwin for the integrated terminal. The "Do you allow this workspace to modify your terminal shell?" comes up *every single time* I open this workspace, which is absolutely painful (requires using the mouse) when I *always* allow it. 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1386467/64657849-593d5f80-d474-11e9-9afe-7b25605e6b42.png)

This wouldn't be such an issue if it just showed up the first time I opened vscode, but it also shows up every time I duplicate the workspace as well (which I do regularly).

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1386467/64657956-cd780300-d474-11e9-9783-9e929e2f13a4.png)

Is it possible to get an option to "Remember for this workspace", or at least to not ask every time I duplicate a workspace if I had already allowed/disallowed?

title: Let me cancel a Find in Files operation
body:
Node Projects with a `node_modules` directory are often so massively huge with files and folders that if you accidentally do a "Find in Files" search that includes it, the entire application hangs while it overloads itself doing a massive search.

I would like to be able to press the escape key or similar to immediately cancel a search-in-progress. There needs to be some kind of UI responsiveness during a search to allow it to be cancelled.

Currently, I have to force-quit the application, or wait 10+ minutes for the search to complete.

title: Unnecessary code and decoration with :after prevents dnd
